But today, I'm going to show you three 
alternatives to tomato sauce
to put between your pizza dough and your topping.
Number one, this is a classic white sauce

but it's flavored with bay and nutmeg, 
and finished with a little bit of cheese.
So first off, a roux.
That's about a tablespoon of butter melted into a small saucepan.
When it's melted, add a tablespoon of flour.
Cook it until you have a paste,
then add whole milk a little bit at a time,
continually stirring and not adding more milk
until the last block is absorbed.

As we're making this sauce, we're going 
to season it with a couple of bay leaves.
They just cook out in the sauce while it thickens
and a grating of nutmeg.
Once you're happy with the consistency of the sauce,
and that's something you can spread over a pizza,
but it's not going to run off the side,
it's a kind of a thick custard consistency,
then grate in some cheese,
and then cook it out for two minutes on a really gentle bubble.
Hot pizza stone.
Brilliant, classic dough season just with garlic powder,
and then that white sauce.
Sometimes it's easier if it's cooled a little bit,
you just need to get rid of the skin.
Look at that, spread it right to the edges.
It is already cheesy,
it's got that amazing nutmeg in it,
and then keep topping simple spring onion,
olive,
and rosemary.
Pizza sauce number one,
it's a cheese sauce with nutmeg and bay ready to go.
Number two, a pesto sauce.
Now, it's used commonly on flat breads,
but less often on pizza.
All you need to do is blend up fresh basil with pine nuts,
a clove of garlic,
some parmesan,
and olive oil, then season to taste.
So with the beauty of the pesto,
which you can see how vibrant it is because of the basil,
we'll pair it with tomato,
roasted red peppers,
pine nuts,
and mozzarella.
Back in the oven.
That's pizza number two, with a pesto sauce, ready to go.
Number three, almost more French than Italian,
it's a black olive tapenade.
All we need to do is blitz up drained and pitted black olives
with anchovies,
parsley,
garlic,
oil,
and then season to taste, but not too much salt
because the olives are like which have been in brine,
and your anchovies are pretty saucy already.
Which is black pepper's good.
A little splash of water to loosen it, if it needs it.
Now tapenade is seriously strong in flavors.
You don't need too much of it,
and I've topped it with more red onion,
red pepper,
mascarpone cheese,
and a grating of parmesan.
That goes back in the oven.
And there you go.
Three completely different pizzas,
and not a tomato sauce inside.
